ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A wider horizon of the scholarship on the history of the Israelite religion; an updated understanding of the academia.
I learned a lot of history and methods of analyzing that history.
Wider knowledge of ancient Israelite religion, archaeology, and history; in particular, I gained new insights on the phenomenon of prophecy and the office of the priesthood in the ancient Near East.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The topics are various and the courses are very informative.
I think that it could have a bit more structure so that it is more clear what we should be learning and what is extra information.

The material was clearly outlined from the beginning of the course. Professor Wilson introduced each topic properly at the outset of each lecture, and he always connected it with the topics that were already covered or were going to be covered. Due to the high volume of information that was covered each week though, one thing that could be considered going forward is stressing which points are most important. However, given that previous material was often referenced in the lectures, the essential points seem to have been revisited.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in this topic.
Yes! Well, it is the only course that does anything with anicent Israelite religion so it is necessary information unavailable otherwise.
Yes, because I think its really good foundation for other Hebrew Bible courses.

Yes, the study of Israelite religion is imperative for any student of the Bible. The secondary literature that we were assigned was arguably the most beneficial aspect of the course for me, as I needed to be exposed to the most influential scholarship in the field, which Professor Wilson was intimately familiar with.
